item.title: Sudoless Kicksecure
item.dc:creator: @ike
item.description:
ike:

That is a very easy systemd setting. Also, I think in recent Debian, including bullseye, it is the default, so no research is needed.

Is it possible that installing Kicksecure disables this? I have 3 Debian bullseye VMs, and the 2 that don’t (yet) have Kicksecure have networking in recovery mode - specifically, the ifup@ens3.service is active. And apt update works. But the VM with Kicksecure does not have networking by default in recovery mode. Was that done intentionally or by accident?

The easy way to fix it is to add a networking service wants link for the rescue target:

mkdir -p /etc/systemd/system/rescue.target.wants
ln -s /lib/systemd/system/networking.service /etc/systemd/system/rescue.target.wants/

item.title: Sudoless Kicksecure
item.dc:creator: @ike
item.description:
Patrick

Interesting!
This is giving a root shell but not requiring any authentication?
So you’re working on a sudo alternative?
I am not sure how that fits in here.

I am considering going sudo-less with root account locked, and I don’t know how much of kicksecure I can incorporate into that. This openvt suid code is probably how I will proceed, as I now consider it a better alternative than rescue mode, as I can use it during normal operation without rebooting. My point to posting it is to show that rescue mode does not need to be the only way to do root tasks when going sudo-less with root locked. If relying on an unproven rescue mode was the original reason for the reluctance to do a sudo-less Kicksecure.

Patrick:

How do enable networking functional from rescue mode? It’s likely possible but I think it’s undocumented and non-trivial to research.

That is a very easy systemd setting. Also, I think in recent Debian, including bullseye, it is the default, so no research is needed.

item.title: Sudoless Kicksecure
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
ike:

Then require that the rest of the install of kicksecure be done in rescue mode (probably safer anyway).

How do enable networking functional from rescue mode? It’s likely possible but I think it’s undocumented and non-trivial to research.

The next planned evolution of Kicksecure is however proving an ISO installation method (easier).
I won’t be working on installation distribution morphing during Debian recovery mode.

item.title: Sudoless Kicksecure
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Interesting!
This is giving a root shell but not requiring any authentication?
So you’re working on a sudo alternative?
I am not sure how that fits in here.

item.title: Sudoless Kicksecure
item.dc:creator: @ike
item.description:
Back on topic: Sudoless Kicksecure. Addressing the issue about how robust the rescue boot forcing root logins is by having an alternative way to get to root that is just as secure as a rescue boot, and more secure than sudo, su, polkit, etc. as those are all susceptible to programmatic attacks by malicious software, and to misconfiguration errors.
Below is a very small C program for a suid exe that will open a root console and switch back when the console exits. This is a secure way to get to root during a normally booted (non-rescue) X or console session, and works even if the root account is locked. I have tested that it works, and it seems secure on my own judgement, but would appreciate other opinions. Obviously, if on a multi-user system use file permissions to only allow execution by users who can be trusted with root capabilities.

#include <fcntl.h>
#include <unistd.h>

#define OPENVT "/usr/bin/openvt"

/* Establish a very basic and safe environment for the VT session.  Note:
 * if we don't set SHELL, then a very simple attack would be to set SHELL
 * to a malicious exe and run this suid, with the result that the malicious
 * exe would get root privileges. */
char *vtenv[] = {
	"PATH=/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin",
	"SHELL=/usr/bin/bash",
	"TERM=linux",
	"LOGNAME=root",
	"HOME=/root",
	"USER=root",
	NULL};

int main() {
	/* really become root: */
	setreuid(0, 0);
	setregid(0, 0);
	/* null-out stdin,stdout,stderr to prevent redirect-IO attacks: */
	int nullfp = open("/dev/null", O_RDWR);
	dup2(nullfp, 0);
	dup2(nullfp, 1);
	dup2(nullfp, 2);
	/* openvt options used:
	 * -l makes it a login session by prefixing the shell with '-'
	 * -s switches to the VT
	 * -w waits for exit from the VT and switches back
	 * The problem with using -e /usr/bin/bash instead of setting SHELL to /usr/bin/bash
	 * is that -e interferes with -w.
	 * */
	execle(OPENVT,OPENVT,"-lsw",NULL,vtenv);
	return 0;
}

item.title: Kicksecure-xfce-host not installable in debian 12 (removed dependency)
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Whonix Forum – 19 Nov 22

[Help Welcome] KVM Development - staying the course

I think we can go ahead and rip out the qxl dependency in whonix and KS as it is now obsolete and we no longer use the graphics device in question. @Patrick

item.title: Kicksecure-xfce-host not installable in debian 12 (removed dependency)
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
HulaHoop:

@nurmagoz any problems when removing it from a running install?

This is easier said than done. Since a meta package depends on the QXL package, makes it hard to remove it. Let alone removing any dependencies that QXL Depends: on. I don’t think any user will be capable of doing that.

related:

Kicksecure – 15 Oct 22

Debian Packages

Which Kicksecure ™ Debian packages are safe to remove? What is a meta package? What other packages do Kicksecure ™ meta packages install? Which packages should never be removed?

item.title: Kicksecure-xfce-host not installable in debian 12 (removed dependency)
item.dc:creator: @nurmagoz
item.description:
hmm not sure i get what do you mean by “removing it from a running
install” do you have specific instructions how to do that?

item.title: Remove/Replace broken links at kicksecure.com
item.dc:creator: @nurmagoz
item.description:
Awesome!

Note: for https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1180410 link is redirecting
to https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/1180405.1180410 (sometimes it takes
long time to redirect which might show its dead)

So its better to replace it with the direct link for it.

Hello, thanks for your patience. I went ahead and filled out the things on the wiki that I could find on Alpine’s wiki and their organization’s site. I also included references for more information. I hope this helps,
-Quill

item.title: Kicksecure-xfce-host not installable in debian 12 (removed dependency)
item.dc:creator: @HulaHoop
item.description: I think QXL gpu has been deprecated in favor of virtio-gpu which means qxl support packages are obsolete and may no longer be needed. @nurmagoz any problems when removing it from a running install?

item.title: Kicksecure-xfce-host not installable in debian 12 (removed dependency)
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Whonix Forum – 6 Nov 22

Higher resolution desktop

If Debian fixed #1004154 - xserver-xorg-video-qxl: XOrg frequently crashes when using qxl driver: qxl(0): error doing QXL_ALLOC - Debian Bug report logs this Debian testing migration bug might fix itself. But if not, then I don’t know.

item.title: Kicksecure-xfce-host not installable in debian 12 (removed dependency)
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Affects Kicksecure KVM only.

Whonix is also affected, reported here just now:

Whonix Forum – 6 Nov 22

Higher resolution desktop

xserver-xorg-video-qxl - Debian Package Tracker Migration status for xserver-xorg-video-qxl (- to 0.1.5+git20200331-3): BLOCKED: Rejected/violates migration policy/introduces a regression Issues preventing migration: ∙ ∙ Updating...

If not resolved at time when porting to Debian 12, I would have to remove that dependency package.

I am not a maintainer of Kicksecure KVM.

//cc @HulaHoop

item.title: Sudoless Kicksecure
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
ike:

But is there anything kicksecure adds that prevents X key loggers?

Could you please open separate forum threads for completely separate topics? That’s because this forum is also used as an issue tracker and if something is missing, it serves as a ticket, documents any missing features and might even lead to these features being implemented one day.

item.title: Sudoless Kicksecure
item.dc:creator: @ike
item.description:
Patrick:

It’s probably not needed but you’d need to be a very advanced user to understand, change the source code.

It’s not worth pursuing unless there is considerable interest in going sudoless with no root logins allowed (except rescue boots). I’m new here, so I don’t have any idea how much interest there is on this. As an alternative, I noticed that kicksecure puts in protections against brute-forcing passwords. But is there anything kicksecure adds that prevents X key loggers? I don’t know of any such tech short of using wayland with xwayland disabled. But, IMHO wayland environments don’t (yet) provide the stability of X running some tried-and-true window manager. So, if using X, going passwordless is a better way to prevent password attacks.

item.title: Add/Remove Extra Packages
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
nurmagoz:

Add Atril or Xpdf as local pdf reader.

Done xpdf.

nurmagoz:

Add Hexchat as IRC client

Waiting for more user requests.

nurmagoz:

Add PGA as graphical PGP generator

Done for gpa.

nurmagoz:

Add hunspell-en-us as english dictionary

Done.

nurmagoz:

Add youtube-dl […]

Done.

nurmagoz:

Add anon-connection-wizard to control Tor connection in graphical way

That would be nice but anon-connection-wizard isn’t compatible with Kicksecure yet. Help welcome.

nurmagoz:
  • zulucrypt-gui for local encryption of folders and files (exist in kicksecure-metapackages but not installed by default)

Meta package non-qubes-vm-enhancements-gui Depend: on it. So it’s installed by default in Kicksecure. But not in Kicksecure for Qubes. That’s on purpose. In Qubes, device encryption would be handled differently and no device would be attached directly to a Kicksecure based Qube? Seems a pretty specific use case. In which case, it would be up to the user to set that up

Waiting for more user requests.

nurmagoz:

Remove:

  • codecrypt as its dead/deprecated

Answered here:

Whonix Forum – 5 Nov 22

post-quantum cryptography - PQC

Why? Is its main functionality or cryptography broken?

github.com/Kicksecure/kicksecure-meta-packages

install more packages by default

committed 01:29PM - 05 Nov 22 UTC
adrelanos
+5 -5

- hunspell-en-us - gpa - ffmpeg - pinentry-qt (or pinentry-x11) - pdf - youtube-…dl https://forums.kicksecure.com/t/add-remove-extra-packages/135/4

item.title: Add/Remove Extra Packages
item.dc:creator: @nurmagoz
item.description:
Add:

  • Add Atril or Xpdf as local pdf reader.
  • Add Hexchat as IRC client
  • Add PGA as graphical PGP generator
  • Add hunspell-en-us as english dictionary
  • Add youtube-dl for downloading youtube and other websites videos
  • Add anon-connection-wizard to control Tor connection in graphical way
  • zulucrypt-gui for local encryption of folders and files (exist in kicksecure-metapackages but not installed by default)

Remove:

  • codecrypt as its dead/deprecated

item.title: Remove/Replace broken links at kicksecure.com
item.dc:creator: @nurmagoz
item.description:
If we view the source code of https://www.kicksecure.com/ page there are:

1- Search for forums.kicksecure.org

<a href="https://forums.kicksecure.org" data-modal="modal-explain-community" target="_blank">

there is no kicksecure.org, it should be .com

2- Search for https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1180410

<a target="_blank" class="external text" href="https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=1180410">
  de-anonymization of Tor onion services

URL broken/changed, check if it can be replaced entirely or with archive one.

3- There is no anbox homepage for anbox-kicksecure feature

Kicksecure – 4 Nov 22

Anbox

4- /wiki/Verify_the_Whonix_images → https://www.kicksecure.com/wiki/Verify_the_Whonix_images → Doesnt exist

  <p>
    Downloads are
    <a href="/wiki/Verifying_Software_Signatures">signed</a>
    so genuine Whonix releases can be
    <a href="/wiki/Verify_the_Whonix_images">verified</a>.
  </p>

Remove wget since its not upstream default and less secure than curl (kicksecure support scurl),

VLC media player.

Done.

nurmagoz:

Thunderbird.

Not sure. Encrypted Email with Thunderbird is complete but no documentation exists for Thunderbird in Kicksecure at time of writing.

Kicksecure – 24 Jul 22

Email Overview

Waiting if there will be high demand for this one which I doubt.

item.title: Sudoless Kicksecure
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description:
Clean Installing KS On Debian 11 CLI, Hit Security Misc Error

However, it implies that maybe sudo isn’t needed after installation.

It’s probably not needed but you’d need to be a very advanced user to understand, change the source code.

ike:

As long as that is put in place first and tested, is there a remaining fear of admin lockout?

It’s untested and at time of writing there’s no CI test yet to make sure the recovery mode is always functional either.

Kicksecure – 1 Sep 22

Undocumented, Untested or Unsupported Features

This feature is either undocumented, untested, or unsupported. Options: Become a Contributor / Apply Free Support Principle / Purchase Professional Support.

Clean Installing KS On Debian 11 CLI, Hit Security Misc Error

Also, on the topic of sudo: has anyone doing kicksecure devo thought about a lighter weight and potentially more secure alternative, like siduction’s doas command?

No contributor was ever working on it and it’s not on the roadmap.

Bug Reports, Software Development and Feature Requests chapter Community Feedback in Kicksecure wiki applies.

item.title: Clean Installing KS On Debian 11 CLI, Hit Security Misc Error
item.dc:creator: @Patrick
item.description: 5 posts were split to a new topic: Sudoless Kicksecure

item.title: Sudoless Kicksecure
item.dc:creator: @ike
item.description: Oh - kicksecure already has that SYSTEMD_SULOGIN_FORCE dropin file (named override.conf - but the name doesn’t matter). As long as that is put in place first and tested, is there a remaining fear of admin lockout?
